title: Ancient & Modern Wonders
description: Test your knowledge of the world's most magnificent structures and landmarks!

questions.question: Which of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World is still standing today?
questions.explanation: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only one of the original Seven Wonders still largely intact, built around 2560 BC.

questions.question: In which country is Machu Picchu located?
questions.explanation: Machu Picchu is a 15th-century Incan citadel situated high in the Andes Mountains of Peru.

questions.question: Which ancient wonder was a giant statue that stood at the entrance to a harbor on a Greek island?
questions.explanation: The Colossus of Rhodes was a 100-foot bronze statue of the sun god Helios, erected in 280 BC on the island of Rhodes.

questions.question: The Taj Mahal was built as a monument to what?
questions.explanation: Emperor Shah Jahan built the Taj Mahal in Agra, India as a mausoleum for his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal, who died in 1631.

questions.question: Which of these is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World?
questions.explanation: Christ the Redeemer in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil was voted one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in 2007.

questions.question: What was the Lighthouse of Alexandria also known as?
questions.explanation: The Pharos of Alexandria was one of the tallest man-made structures in the ancient world, standing about 330 feet tall.

questions.question: The Colosseum in Rome could hold approximately how many spectators?
questions.explanation: The Colosseum, completed in 80 AD, could hold between 50,000 and 80,000 spectators for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.

questions.question: Which ancient city was carved directly into red sandstone cliffs?
questions.explanation: Petra in modern-day Jordan was carved into rose-red sandstone cliffs by the Nabataeans over 2,000 years ago.

questions.question: How long is the Great Wall of China?
questions.explanation: Including all its branches, the Great Wall stretches approximately 13,171 miles (21,196 km), built over many centuries.

questions.question: The Hanging Gardens of Babylon were supposedly built in which modern-day country?
questions.explanation: Ancient Babylon was located near modern-day Hillah in Iraq, though the existence of the gardens is still debated by historians.

questions.question: Which wonder was a massive temple built to honor the Greek goddess Artemis?
questions.explanation: The Temple of Artemis at Ephesus (in modern-day Turkey) was one of the Seven Wonders, rebuilt three times before its final destruction.

questions.question: The Panama Canal connects which two bodies of water?
options: Caribbean Sea and Gulf of Mexico
questions.explanation: The Panama Canal, completed in 1914, connects the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans through a 50-mile waterway across Panama.

questions.question: Angkor Wat in Cambodia is the world's largest what?
questions.explanation: Angkor Wat is the world's largest religious monument, originally built as a Hindu temple in the 12th century.

questions.question: Which modern wonder was designed by Gustave Eiffel and completed in 1889?
questions.explanation: The Eiffel Tower was built for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. Originally controversial, it became France's most iconic landmark.

questions.question: The ancient city of Chichen Itza is located in which country?
questions.explanation: Chichen Itza is a large Mayan archaeological site on the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico, famous for the pyramid of Kukulkan.

questions.question: Which ancient wonder was a giant seated statue made of ivory and gold?
questions.explanation: The Statue of Zeus at Olympia was a 40-foot chryselephantine (ivory and gold) sculpture created by the sculptor Phidias around 435 BC.

questions.question: The Terracotta Army was discovered near which Chinese city?
questions.explanation: The Terracotta Army of over 8,000 life-sized figures was discovered near Xi'an in 1974, guarding the tomb of Emperor Qin Shi Huang.

questions.question: What is the Mausoleum at Halicarnassus named after?
options: King Mausolus who was buried there
The Greek god of the underworld
questions.explanation: The word 'mausoleum' itself comes from King Mausolus of Caria, whose elaborate tomb was built around 350 BC.

questions.question: The Moai statues are found on which island?
questions.explanation: Nearly 900 giant Moai statues were carved by the Rapa Nui people on Easter Island (Rapa Nui) between 1250 and 1500 AD.

questions.question: Which modern engineering wonder is the world's tallest building as of 2024?
questions.explanation: The Burj Khalifa in Dubai stands at 2,717 feet (828 meters) and has held the record for world's tallest building since its completion in 2010.
